Introduction

Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) is the mechanism of allowing Trust employees to bring personally owned IT devices (such as laptops, tablets and smart phones) to the Trust, connect these devices to the Trust IT network, and use these devices to access Trust information and applications. This definition also covers the issuing of Trust mobile devices such as tablet devices where they support the business need.

The use of BYOD presents a number of benefits by making the access to the information and applications required to deliver patient care in a more flexible manner without the need for a Trust provided desktop or laptop device. This means patient care can be delivered directly to the patient bedside with patient information updated in real time. It also presents potential cost savings to the Trust at a time when the demand for IT delivered services are rising yet the funds available for more Trust IT devices is falling.
Scope

This policy applies to employees, contractors, business consultants, temporaries, and other workers, including all personnel affiliated with third parties of Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.

The remainder of this document will define how users can apply for and, following approval, can gain access to Trust infrastructure and system as appropriate for their role. It will also set out the conditions of use and the expectation of staffs' conduct whilst connected/accessing Trust systems.

Allowing BYOD devices' connection to the Trust IT network could represent a significant risk to Trust information if not implemented and managed correctly. This policy aims to outline processes to mitigate the following risks areas:
Exposure of Trust data
Password exposure
Application compatibility issues.
Network bandwidth overuse
Virus infections
This policy defines how personally owned devices are connected to Trust infrastructure and used whilst undertaking Trust business.
It applies to all users who have been granted access to Trust IT computer systems and encompasses access, or attempted access, to Trust systems and infrastructure including OWA Webmail and NHSMail.
The purpose of this document is to:
Set out who may legitimately request BYOD access.
Set out how BYOD access is granted.
Define what BYOD devices may connect and how such connection is secured.
Define the approved applications and information
Set out the general rules for BYOD access and set out users responsibilities.

data.text: Roles & Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1 Digital Services Governance Group – to review policies and recommend for group approval.
4.1.2 Information Governance Group – to review any instances of non-compliance to stated policy.
4.1.3 Joint Document Management Group – to ratify polices
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
4.2.1 Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO) – Joint Executive Group (JEG) appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious information risk management issues are brought to the Board for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Group's approach to information risk management.
Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards regarding the information risk management content of the annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.2 Caldicott Guardian – Board appointed Site Director for each Trust is responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of PCD processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PCD.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of PCD where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework.
4.2.3 Head of Digital Services, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for development and updating of Digital Services Policies.
4.2.4 Head of Information Governance, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for information governance.
4.2.5 Line Managers
Responsible for ensuring that staff are aware of this policy that they adhere to it and for managing issues which arise when staff fail to comply.
4.2.6 Trust Staff
Responsible for implementing and complying with the policy within the areas of their responsibility or control.
Policy Requirements
Requesting Access to Connect User Owned Devices

5.1.1 All Trust staff, including associates and approved third parties, wishing to connect a personal device to Trust services must have a Service Request raised through the IT Self-Service Portal by the line manager or suitable Trust representative, detailing the business reason for access and the device they wish to connect.
5.1.2 Each access request will be reviewed to ensure there is a satisfactory business requirement and that the BYOD device access is being requested from an approved source.

5.1.3 If authorisation is approved the user will be supplied details on how to connect the BYOD device to Trust services. This information is for the user only and must not be shared or used to connect non-authorised BYOD devices. Any additional BYOD devices the user wishes to connect must be authorised via an additional access request.

5.1.4 The user must configure an appropriate access password on the BYOD device to protect it from unauthorised access. As a security measure against device loss or theft BYOD devices must be set to require the password to be re-entered if the device is unused for a minimum of 10 minutes. The BYOD device must also be configured to wipe itself after an defined number of failed password attempts.
5.1.5 It is a condition of the use of IT and BYOD access provided by the Trust, that the user agrees to be bound by the relevant Policies and Regulations.
BYOD Access & Usage

5.2.1 To facilitate the connection of a BYOD device to the IT network a dedicated wireless network has been created. Authentication on this network is provided by 802.1x network access control. Interaction between this dedicated BYOD wireless network and the main Trust IT network is strictly controlled.
5.2.2 Access to connect a personal IT device to the Trust BYOD wireless network is controlled differently at each site:

At Southend site an MDM solution (currently supplied by Sophos) is utilised. After the user is authorised to use a personal device by the IT Service Desk they are given access to enrol their device to the MDM.
At Basildon and Mid Essex staff may connect their BYOD devices to the Trusts segregated network (BTUH_Mob and Staff-Wifi respectively) utilising their Active Directory Credentials.

5.2.3 At Southend the enrolment process will automatically configure the device to connect to the Trust BYOD WiFi network as well as checking for particular security settings such as encrypted storage. If these policies are not met at either time of enrolment or any time in the future the device will be automatically removed from the Trust network.

5.2.4 If the BYOD device is lost or stolen the user must advise IT immediately. IT can action a number of things to ensure the device can no longer access the Trust network; this includes removing the Wi-Fi settings from the device using the MDM, remotely wiping the device or disabling the user account associated with the device.

5.2.5 Users must not have their devices configured to cache passwords on the BYOD device. This means when logging into a system (such as e-mail) they must not check any boxes to remember the password. This will prevent this information being put at risk if the BYOD device is lost or stolen.

5.2.6 Users must not use the applications installed on their BYOD device in such a way that it could have a negative impact on the Trust business. This includes playing games etc., unless it is during the users own time (e.g. scheduled breaks).
5.2.7 Users must not take screenshots of the displayed information when using Trust applications on their BYOD device.
5.2.8 The Trust IT Service Desk will provide support for the access and usage of Trust applications but will not provide support for the BYOD device itself.

5.2.9 If the BYOD device is broken or lost it is down the user to ensure there are appropriate measures in place to ensure their work is not disrupted in such a way that could adversely affect Trust business.

5.2.10 When the BYOD device is used while sitting down it will be subject to the same conditions as the current Trust desktop screen (DSE) assessment. If the BYOD device is used when walking around it will be subject to the same conditions as the current Trust manual handling policies. Users should be familiar with both sets of information.
5.2.11 If a user sustains an injury, to themselves or others, through the use of the BYOD device the Trust will not be held liable.

5.2.12 Users must ensure that they use appropriate hand washing actions after using the BYOD device and that the device is not used in areas where infection control might be compromised in line with the Trusts infection control strategy.
Accessing Trust Applications
5.3.1 Access to the Trust e-mail system will also be provided so that users can view Trust e-mail without having to launch Microsoft Outlook from Citrix e.g.
Outlook Web Access (https://connect.southend.nhs.uk, https://connect.btuh.nhs.uk, https://owa.meht.nhs.uk)

Native e-mail applications – these will only be able available on devices that meet the device encryption requirements, see associated policies for further information, and by approval of a Service Request for Push Mail through the IT Self-Service Portal.

5.3.2 Internet access will be available via a dedicated web filtering appliance linked to the Trust N3 internet connection. The appliance will provide the filtering of inappropriate internet sites and downloads (in line with current User Access & Acceptable Usage of IT Policy) and bandwidth management to ensure there is minimal impact on current Trust data traffic.

5.3.3 Any requests for other Trust systems to be made available to BYOD devices on the BYOD wireless network at Southend (e.g. a web page for a patient system) will be reviewed on a case by case basis to ensure that the delivery method is secure and compatible. A list of applications that are approved will be maintained in the Appendix

5.3.4 It is particularly important that an application (app) on any mobile device is not used for Trust business without first considering information governance legislation, and Trust policies and procedures.

5.3.5 Some clinical applications, especially those which advise clinical decisions can be considered as ‘clinical devices' and must be more stringently considered and agreed through information governance and the Medical Equipment Service departments at each site.

5.3.6 Under no circumstance should PII, PID or PCD be transmitted using an app on a personal mobile device. All transfers of information must comply with existing registered information sharing agreements (ISA).

5.3.7 Non-compliance could result in disciplinary action in line with the Trust disciplinary policy, substantial financial penalties and legal action against the Trust and individuals concerned. Screen saver time out and password protection policies are applied to all systems which connect to the Trust network.
Approved Devices
5.4.1  Only approved devices may connect to the BYOD wireless network; the approved BYOD device list is based on operating system version (both mobile and desktop) and can be found in Appendix
Security Measures
5.5.1 To ensure Trust data is still secured when accessed from a BYOD device attached to the Trusts solutions, a number of measures have been put in place.
5.5.2 The BYOD wireless network is logically segregated from the main Trust IT network via firewalls and port control.
5.5.3 The only services allowed to access the main Trust IT network are detailed in Appendix

5.5.4 Access to connect a BYOD device to the BYOD wireless network is controlled at Southend by an MDM solution and Active Directory (AD) authentication, whilst current Basildon and Mid Essex employ Active Directory (AD) authentication. This means that the device has been stringently reviewed and constantly monitored for security compliance as well as the user must already have a Trust IT access account and any unauthorised users who try to connect will not be able to do so.
5.5.5 Any additional applications that will be made available via the BYOD wireless network will be assessed for information governance risk and appropriate measures put in place.
Obligations of staff and line managers on termination of employment

5.6.1  When the user leaves the Trust it is the responsibility of the user or their line manager to inform IT so the BYOD access can be revoked. This is necessary to ensure the personal device is no longer able to access the BYOD wireless network.
Training Requirements

No specific training requirements have been identified however staff are expected to ensure that they keep up to date regarding IG and IT/Cyber security update emails and messages published in staff circulars.
Monitoring & Audit
In addition to the legal liabilities outlined above, staff who breach any of the terms of this policy may be subject to disciplinary action.
Access by BYOD device to Trust infrastructure will be monitored as follows:

Appendix 1: Approved Mobile Devices for BYOD Access
1) Trust issued devices

The Trust may issue devices that can be used for access on the BYOD wireless network. This device will be specific to the business units' requirements and be in line with the approved personal mobile device list below.
2) Approved personal mobile devices
The following is the list of personal mobile devices currently authorised for access to the Trust BYOD wireless network.
The devices must be used in line with the guidelines in the BYOD policy including:
The mobile operating system (OS) must be uncompromised at the OS level (iOS jail breaking, Android rooting).
The desktop OS must be fully security patched.
The OS and any additional storage must be encrypted.
The  desktop  OS  must  have  anti-virus  (AV)  software  installed  and  updated regularly.

table_items.text: At the current time the users will be using the iPads to browse to the web site that has been installed on your own server (so there is no internet access). The only data that is displayed on the device by our web pages is site information (the functional areas in the property, and the rooms in those areas), however this information is NOT stored anywhere on the device (it is just displayed within the pages themselves). The users will then mark off any elements within the selected room that are found to be not clean (i.e., the locker is dirty, the window is smeared, etc.) and these results are then saved back up to the server with nothing being saved/left on the device. For your information though, we are in the process of creating an application that WILL store the above data (what elements were found to be not clean in which rooms/areas) on the mobile device (this has not been completed yet and so Allison and her colleagues do not have it). We do not think though that this is critical or sensitive information. In short, we do not believe that any sensitive (or critical) information is held on the mobile device in relation to carrying out C4C audits (now or in the future).
